description:
The boy’s mother returned home from work one day and saw her son sitting on the teacher’s lap in their living room. She felt that something was amiss. 

“At that moment, I already don’t feel good,” the mother said while sobbing, “because my supervisor had ever told me she saw (my son) sitting on (the man’s) lap at the void deck and he was hugging and kissing at, like, his neck, ears, cheek and mouth.”

But she didn’t say anything, because her 12-year-old son’s primary school teacher had grown to be like a family member, lending her money on several occasions and even taking on the role as the boy’s guardian.

Then came the day she allowed the boy to go over to the man’s place for a sleepover...

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
While overseeing alteration works at a house, Mr Koh Kok Heng, 53, fell through a floor opening and landed on a staircase about 4.7m below.

His sons rushed to the hospital when they heard the news, but by the time they arrived, it was too late. Their father had already died.

MOM said that the accident is the fourth fatal workplace incident here since the start of February. 

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#workplaceaccident #accident #construction #workplacesafety #constructionlife #cny2021 #reuniondinner #chinesenewyear #family #rip

description:
“If found to have falsely declared their educational qualifications, their work passes will be immediately revoked and they will be permanently barred from employment in Singapore,” MOM said in a media statement.

The Manav Bharti University is a private university in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, which was exposed earlier this month by local authorities for having sold fake degrees across India for a period of 11 years, according to reports. 

Of the 41,000 degrees issued by the university so far, only 5,000 have been found to be genuine...

description:
The woman, 39, was standing next to Dr Shen Ruifu, 54, on an MRT train when she felt him scratching her inner thigh over her skirt. 

Shen holds a doctorate degree in geotechnical engineering from the National University of Singapore (NUS).

In mitigation, Shen's lawyer said that Shen did not specifically target the victim and that the act was committed in the spur of the moment, with no skin-to-skin contact. 

After the offence, the court heard that Shen had also made donations to gender equality advocacy group Association of Women for Action and Research (Aware)...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
🍪 The 35-year-old former Mediacorp actress had no intention of starting a business selling cookies. In fact, it was something she stumbled upon as she was preparing to launch her jewellery business. 

Her suppliers, she says, "send their cookies to four or five-star hotels, so they’re good stuff", adding that her family is also in the food business, "so I was blessed to have been able to get these suppliers on board in such a short time frame".

Tracy’s late husband, Ben Goi, was the son of 'Popiah King' Sam Goi, who is the chairman of food manufacturer Tee Yih Jia Food. Ben passed away in 2019 from a stroke caused by a brain haemorrhage.

Tracy tells @8dayssg @8days_eat that she originally intended to add laksa cookies and curry puff cookies to her menu, but was unable to do so as she's too busy caring for her two-year-old son, Ben Junior. She decided to homeschool Ben Junior when...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @tracyleemeileng / Instagram

description:
Photos of Singapore-based Leia and Lauren, identical twins now aged five, have been posted on Instagram since they were born. People around the world have enjoyed their antics, their daily activities and travels around the world with their parents, Mr Peter Lok and Ms Ember Yong.

The success of the twins' social media account has seen Mr Lok, 44, and Ms Yong, 37, collaborate with many brands, earning free stays worldwide, toys and meals, among other things. 

Although they are unwilling to say how much they make from the twins' social media presence, it's known that successful mommy blogs in Singapore can make up to S$25,000 per sponsored post.

The word "sharenting" has been coined to describe sharing the joys and challenges of parenthood on social media through streams of photos, videos and stories. But should parents be more concerned about what they make public?

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: @leialauren / @instagram 

#sharenting #sharentingparenting #sgparents #sgkids #sginfluencer #parenting #family #socialmedia #kidsofinstagram #kidsofig

description:
Yesterday, Mr Joe Biden became the 46th president of the United States, vowing a "new day" for the United States after four years of tumult under Mr Donald Trump who in an extraordinary final act snubbed the inauguration.

Two weeks to the day after Trump supporters violently rampaged at the US Capitol to overturn the election results, Mr Biden took the oath on the same very steps alongside Ms Kamala Harris, who was sworn in moments earlier as the first woman vice-president.

Mr Biden, putting his hand on a family Bible, repeated after Chief Justice John Roberts the presidential oath — that he will "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States".

Mr Biden, who at 78 is the oldest president in US history and only the second Catholic, took office amid enormous challenges with the still-raging Covid-19 pandemic having claimed 400,000 lives in the United States.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Reuters

comments: Stay strong to all Malaysians here in Singapore. Jia you
description:
🇲🇾 Mr Wong Wai Theng, 35, who works in the transportation industry, has not returned to his Johor Baru home since March last year. 

“Back then, I thought the country’s borders would only be closed for 14 days. I remember being in tears crossing the Causeway, feeling confused and directionless,’’ he says. 

💔The separation from loved ones in Malaysia, including his girlfriend, was worsened by a bout of dengue fever last June. Many of Mr Wong’s personal plans have been put on hold, including his proposal to his girlfriend. 

“I also haven’t visited my parents for two years. This pandemic has made me realise that I should cherish every moment of separation and the people around me,’’ he says. 

Like him, other Malaysians working in Singapore are not planning to return home for Chinese New Year celebrations this year considering the severity of the Covid-19 pandemic in Malaysia and quarantine cost. 

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline

#cny #cny2021 #malaysia #singapore #malaysialockdown #causeway #covid_19 

Photo: Reuters

description:
🇲🇾 Mr Wong Wai Theng, 35, who works in the transportation industry, has not returned to his Johor Baru home since March last year. 

“Back then, I thought the country’s borders would only be closed for 14 days. I remember being in tears crossing the Causeway, feeling confused and directionless,’’ he says. 

💔The separation from loved ones in Malaysia, including his girlfriend, was worsened by a bout of dengue fever last June. Many of Mr Wong’s personal plans have been put on hold, including his proposal to his girlfriend. 

“I also haven’t visited my parents for two years. This pandemic has made me realise that I should cherish every moment of separation and the people around me,’’ he says. 

Like him, other Malaysians working in Singapore are not planning to return home for Chinese New Year celebrations this year considering the severity of the Covid-19 pandemic in Malaysia and quarantine cost.

description:
Way more than Monday Blues for these workers. 

Mr Park Ki-Ryeon, a courier, hauls a bag of rice up flights of stairs for a customer in Seongnam, a city on the outskirts of Seoul, South Korea. More than a dozen couriers have died last year, some after complaining of unbearable workloads that kept them on the clock from dawn until past midnight.

Elsewhere in Seoul, at a logistics depot the size of an airplane hangar, some couriers held a ritual at the start of another gruelling work day: They stood for a moment of silence to remember fellow couriers who died last year from overwork.

“We won’t be surprised here if one of us drops dead, too,” said Mr Choi Ji-na, one of the couriers. 

Mr Choi, 43, and other delivery workers in South Korea say that they are thankful to have jobs amid growing unemployment. But they are also paying a price. Packages are expected to arrive with “bullet speed,” and the workers delivering them say that it is becoming impossible to keep up with the demand...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#courier #courierservice #couriercompany #deliveryworkerappreciation #seoul #seoulkorea #overworked #mondayblues #hello2021

description:
This unusual hobby has helped Mr Peter Kiew, 72, through family problems and health issues.

While most commuters are bemused and elated at his works, some have their reservations. There have been commuters who accuse him of invading their privacy and even threaten to call the police.

“I will just tell them, if you don’t like what I do, then I’ll tear up the paper,” he said. “When people tell me such things, it goes into one ear and then out the other, I don’t let it bother me.”

It is the happiness of commuters that keeps him doing what he does. The moment he boards an MRT train, he springs to action, whipping out a sketchpad, pencil and eraser, before proceeding to methodically sketch the commuters around him, one by one.

Once the 72-year-old is done with each sketch, he will offer the artwork to the commuter free of charge. He started this hobby in 2014, and that he hardly takes rest days.

TODAY accompanied Mr Kiew as he sketched commuters from Bishan to Jurong East. Click on the link in bio @todayonline to read on.

#singapore #sgart #sgartist #sgsketch #sgsketcher #art #sketch #sketching #mrtart

It is the happiness of commuters that keeps him doing what he does. The moment he boards an MRT train, he springs to action, whipping out a sketchpad, pencil and eraser, before proceeding to methodically sketch the commuters around him, one by one.

Once the 72-year-old is done with each sketch, he will offer the artwork to the commuter free of charge. He started this hobby in 2014, and that he hardly takes rest days.

TODAY accompanied Mr Kiew as he sketched commuters from Bishan to Jurong East. Click on the link in bio @todayonline to read on.

#singapore #sgart #sgartist #sgsketch #sgsketcher #art #sketch #sketching #mrtart

comments: Bless you and your family ♥️
description:
Mr Noel Tan knows first-hand the extent to which a debilitating disease can affect families.

His wife has a relapse of gastric cancer and he has become increasingly familiar with the feelings of overwhelming helplessness that many caregivers of advanced cancer patients have.

They surface whenever he sees his wife Brenda suffering excruciating pain and discomfort. This is the second time in five years that she is stricken by cancer. The couple has three children aged 12, 14 and 21.

Mr Tan, 51, who works as an internal consultant in a pharmaceutical organisation, said: “There have been so many moments where I would feel absolutely helpless. I would be sitting there, unable to do anything for her but to rub her back, give her some water or pray with her.”

During their visits to the National University Cancer Institute, Singapore (NCIS) for her treatment in recent months, it occurred to Mr Tan that other patients and caregivers who have been hit by the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic are possibly struggling to cope during this challenging period.

That thought spurred him to embark on a fundraising project...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#nationaluniversitycancerinstitutesingapore #nationaluniversitycancerinstitute #fundraising #cancerresearch #cancerfund #caregiving #caregiver #caregiversupport

description:
For seven months this year, Mr Zhang Jinlei stayed inside his dormitory room. He could not freely leave its compounds except when work resumed, as part of the authorities’ measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus in Singapore. 

Last month, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) eased movement restrictions for migrant workers living in dormitories and the 36-year-old has been running within the dormitory compounds for half an hour daily. 

Before Covid-19 struck, the construction worker regularly ran outside his dormitory along Tanah Merah Coast Road. 

When asked by reporters how he felt about getting back to his favourite activity, Mr Zhang beamed and said: “Happy!” Clutching his abdomen with both hands, he remarked: “I gained more than 10kg over the few months of the lockdown.”

Mr Annamalai Lokesh, a 26-year-old construction worker from India, said that one of his favourite facilities was the communal kitchen. “(Now it opens) six months after cooking stopped, everyone feels good,” Mr Annamalai said. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#migrantworkerssg #migrantworkerssingapore

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#migrantworkerssg #migrantworkerssingapore

description:
For seven months this year, Mr Zhang Jinlei stayed inside his dormitory room. He could not freely leave its compounds except when work resumed, as part of the authorities’ measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus in Singapore. 

Last month, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) eased movement restrictions for migrant workers living in dormitories and the 36-year-old has been running within the dormitory compounds for half an hour daily. 

Before Covid-19 struck, the construction worker regularly ran outside his dormitory along Tanah Merah Coast Road. 

When asked by reporters how he felt about getting back to his favourite activity, Mr Zhang beamed and said: “Happy!” Clutching his abdomen with both hands, he remarked: “I gained more than 10kg over the few months of the lockdown.”

Mr Annamalai Lokesh, a 26-year-old construction worker from India, said that one of his favourite facilities was the communal kitchen. “(Now it opens) six months after cooking stopped, everyone feels good,” Mr Annamalai said.

description:
The actress wants to let everyone know that it’s okay to not be okay.

In October, the actress’ fanclub @rbkd shared a very emotional post from Rui En, where she revealed that her cat had passed away "completely suddenly and unexpectedly". 

In that post, she wrote: "I have been alternating between feeling OK and breathtaking devastation. The pain is more like an emptiness, a hole that feels like it can never be filled again. I'm afraid to sleep because I want to avoid that moment of waking up feeling everything is ok, only to have that realization that she is gone. I can't eat..."

In a recent interview with @8dayssg, Rui En was asked if she was feeling better. 

She said: "I'm just not someone who wants to have kids, nor someone who feels incomplete without having kids, but we all do have a nurturing side, and I translated that onto my animals.  I really do treat them as my kids, so when you have a child pass away suddenly, it's very traumatic...

"There are certain days where you feel okay, [and] some days where you feel like you might not be okay, and that's okay. It really was the first time for me, [experiencing] this kind of grief and trauma. I did go for some grief counselling via Zoom [with a counsellor from USA], I actually haven't written about it, but I intend to, 'ços I want to normalise mental health care..."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#grief #griefsupport

I did go for some grief counselling via Zoom [with a counsellor from USA], I actually haven't written about it, but I intend to, 'ços I want to normalise mental health care..."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#grief #griefsupport

description:
The actress wants to let everyone know that it’s okay to not be okay.

In October, the actress’ fanclub @rbkd shared a very emotional post from Rui En, where she revealed that her cat had passed away "completely suddenly and unexpectedly". 

In that post, she wrote: "I have been alternating between feeling OK and breathtaking devastation. The pain is more like an emptiness, a hole that feels like it can never be filled again. I'm afraid to sleep because I want to avoid that moment of waking up feeling everything is ok, only to have that realization that she is gone. I can't eat..."

In a recent interview with @8dayssg, Rui En was asked if she was feeling better. 

She said: "I'm just not someone who wants to have kids, nor someone who feels incomplete without having kids, but we all do have a nurturing side, and I translated that onto my animals.  I really do treat them as my kids, so when you have a child pass away suddenly, it's very traumatic...

"There are certain days where you feel okay, [and] some days where you feel like you might not be okay, and that's okay. It really was the first time for me, [experiencing] this kind of grief and trauma. I did go for some grief counselling via Zoom [with a counsellor from USA], I actually haven't written about it, but I intend to, 'ços I want to normalise mental health care..."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#grief #griefsupport

description:
Yesterday, the High Court sentenced a foreign worker to death for murdering his girlfriend, rejecting his claim that she humiliated him right before he killed her.

Ahmed Salim, a 31-year-old Bangladeshi, was convicted of a murder charge, which carries the mandatory death penalty in Singapore. Clad in a purple prison jumpsuit, he was expressionless as the sentence was passed.

Ahmed had admitted to the killing acts but disputed claims that he intended to cause the death of his girlfriend, Indonesian domestic worker Nurhidayati Wartono Surata, on Dec 30, 2018.

The couple had dated for five years and decided to get engaged, but she began seeing other men. When Nurhidayati, then 34, refused to break up with another foreign worker she was dating, he tightened a towel around her neck, then strangled her with a drawstring from his jacket.

During his trial, Ahmed alleged that Nurhidayati had gravely provoked him when she said, in reference to her other boyfriend: “He is better than you, he is better than you in the hotel, he is better in bed, he is better financially. If you don’t believe (me), next week I will go with him, will make a video and show you.”

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline

Ahmed had admitted to the killing acts but disputed claims that he intended to cause the death of his girlfriend, Indonesian domestic worker Nurhidayati Wartono Surata, on Dec 30, 2018.

The couple had dated for five years and decided to get engaged, but she began seeing other men. When Nurhidayati, then 34, refused to break up with another foreign worker she was dating, he tightened a towel around her neck, then strangled her with a drawstring from his jacket.

During his trial, Ahmed alleged that Nurhidayati had gravely provoked him when she said, in reference to her other boyfriend: “He is better than you, he is better than you in the hotel, he is better in bed, he is better financially. If you don’t believe (me), next week I will go with him, will make a video and show you.”

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Fiona Xie @xplacidacidx has a beauty that makes a person, male or female, do a double take when she walks by. So said @quanyifong about Xie, when the latter appeared as a guest on a recent episode of Quan’s talk show, Hear U Out. 

But are her good looks a double-edged sword? Apparently, while her beauty has won her many admirers (even when she was in kindergarten!), it has also led to a number of chilling encounters with those obsessed with her.

She recalls the attention started to get creepy in primary school. I had admirers from other schools, and there was one of them who tried to stalk me,  Fiona said.

“[He] would follow me every day, but that wasn’t the scariest bit. What was terrifying was when he’d call my home number the moment I got back and tell me that he knows what I was wearing and what I was doing. I didn’t know if he was telling the truth but I was so frightened that I drew the curtains shut immediately. I don’t even know who he was," she said. 

This unknown individual even threatened Fiona during these conversations. “He said he would call my mum and speak to her if I hung up on him,  she revealed.  As a child, I couldn’t understand what was going on. I didn’t know what to do, so I told my mother about the incident. It was pretty stressful.”

What else did Fiona say?
Click on the link in bio @todayonline to find out. 

#fionaxie #quanyifong

description:
China had 60 billionaires aged under 40 in 2020, and their combined worth was more than US$223 billion (S$297 billion).

One such individual is 35-year-old Chinese e-commerce star Huang Wei, better known as Viya. She has an estimated net worth of more than US$30 million, generated from live online sales, advertising and virtual gifts.

Her popularity grew during lockdown when online shopping became more important than ever. Millions tuned into Viya's broadcasts, and in April she reached a high of more than 37 million viewers. On the first day of the Singles' Day online shopping bonanza in October, Viya secured 5.32 billion yuan (US$814 million) in sales, Chinese media reported.

With live online shopping continuing to gain momentum, Viya, who has collaborated with American reality television star Kim Kardashian and singer Taylor Swift, is tipped to see her fortune rise even further.

From young tech entrepreneurs and real estate tycoons to celebrities and athletes, read on to find out more about China's wealthiest millennials. 
Click on the link in bio @todayonline. 

#chinabillionaires #billionaire #viya #ecommerce #influencer #tycoon #chinacelebrity #chinainfluencers #chinathletes #chinarichest #chinaentrepreneur #chinamillionaires #richmillennial

Her popularity grew during lockdown when online shopping became more important than ever. Millions tuned into Viya's broadcasts, and in April she reached a high of more than 37 million viewers. On the first day of the Singles' Day online shopping bonanza in October, Viya secured 5.32 billion yuan (US$814 million) in sales, Chinese media reported.

With live online shopping continuing to gain momentum, Viya, who has collaborated with American reality television star Kim Kardashian and singer Taylor Swift, is tipped to see her fortune rise even further.

From young tech entrepreneurs and real estate tycoons to celebrities and athletes, read on to find out more about China's wealthiest millennials. 
Click on the link in bio @todayonline.

comments: HOMAT #runningsupportgroup
description:
"I was only 11 when I saw my last sunset. It was 1998," writes Tan Siew Ling, 33, an administrative assistant at a local company.

"I was not always blind and deaf. During my childhood, when my vision progressively deteriorated, everyone in the family thought it was just myopia."

"That was until we realised that the trips to the optician were becoming a tad too frequent. A visit to an eye specialist and the resulting computerised tomography scan revealed that I was suffering from optic atrophy. I was later diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), a genetic disorder caused by four tumours in my brain."

"For persons with special needs like myself, feeling included is sometimes harder than we hope. After all, we are different from others because of our physical or mental disabilities."

"The onset of Covid-19 exacerbated my overwhelming sense of isolation...Silence was never more deafening and I have never yearned so much for connection with others..."

How does Siew Ling cope, and how did Running Club @runninghour come to support her during her darkest moments?

Find out, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#genyspeaks #communitysupport #mentalhealth #supportinclusion #supportinclusioncelebrateabilities #singapore #specialneeds #integrationthroughsport #runninghour #runningsupportgroup #runninghoursg

How does Siew Ling cope, and how did Running Club @runninghour come to support her during her darkest moments?

Find out, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#genyspeaks #communitysupport #mentalhealth #supportinclusion #supportinclusioncelebrateabilities #singapore #specialneeds #integrationthroughsport #runninghour #runningsupportgroup #runninghoursg

description:
A sexual harassment case that has been hailed as a pioneering moment for China's #MeToo movement in China opened in Beijing earlier this week, and attracted hundreds of supporters for the plaintiff.

Ms Zhou Xiaoxuan, 27, is suing Zhu Jun, a prominent television host whom she accuses of forcibly kissing her in 2014. She is demanding a public apology from Zhu and 50,000 yuan (S$10,201) in damages.

Ms Zhou's case is being closely watched as it followed the passage of China's first Civil Code in May, which provided an expanded definition of sexual harassment and greater protection for victims.

Ms Zhou, who is better known by her nickname Xianzi, alleged that Zhu harassed her when she worked as an intern for state broadcaster CCTV six years ago.

She first posted her allegations online in 2018. Zhu, who denies the claims, unsuccessfully filed a counter lawsuit accusing her of damaging his reputation...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: AFP

#china #chinametoomovement #chinacivilcode

description:
Mirosh Singh, 25, is a part-time Bachelor of Sports and Physical Education with Management student at Singapore University of Social Sciences.

Before 2020, he says: "I was not involved in giving back to the community or in any of my university's community events due to my busy schedule as a personal trainer where I would work six to seven days a week and up to 12 hours a day."

But when Covid-19 struck, the circuit breaker meant he could not meet up with clients for their training. With no income and mounting uncertainties, he knew he had to "grab whatever opportunity came along".

In June, he was hired as a full-time swabber attached to the Health Promotion Board on a six-month contract and has been deployed to various foreign worker dormitories, hotels and sites such as Changi Airport.

He says: "The work is quite tough, in part because I have to don personal protective equipment for up to three hours at a stretch. Being outdoors under hot and humid conditions, I am often completely drenched in perspiration. But I feel a sense of accomplishment."

His ongoing stint as a swabber for up to 42 hours a week has "not only toughened me up", but has also "made me a different person with a broader outlook of life", he says...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#covid_19 #swabtest #swabber #swabsg

But when Covid-19 struck, the circuit breaker meant he could not meet up with clients for their training. With no income and mounting uncertainties, he knew he had to "grab whatever opportunity came along".

In June, he was hired as a full-time swabber attached to the Health Promotion Board on a six-month contract and has been deployed to various foreign worker dormitories, hotels and sites such as Changi Airport.

He says: "The work is quite tough, in part because I have to don personal protective equipment for up to three hours at a stretch. Being outdoors under hot and humid conditions, I am often completely drenched in perspiration. But I feel a sense of accomplishment."

His ongoing stint as a swabber for up to 42 hours a week has "not only toughened me up", but has also "made me a different person with a broader outlook of life", he says...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#covid_19 #swabtest #swabber #swabsg

description:
A Facebook post written by another former employee, which has since made its rounds on social media, claims that her ex-colleague, a young Malaysian worker, had taken her own life in December last year after she faced “constant bullying and insults” by the director of the firm. The post also claimed that her employment was terminated after she failed to achieve sales targets.

The Facebook post was accompanied by a suicide note, which the writer had obtained from the mother of the Malaysian worker.

The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) said that the Malaysian worker did not make a report before her death. Last month, some 11 months later, her mother contacted the ministry on Oct 29.

Why is she raising the incident almost a year after her daughter’s death?
And what did the firm's director have to say, during an interview with @todayonline?

Find out, when you click on the link in bio.

#mom #suicide #investigation #employer #workplacewellness #workplaceculture #workplace #bully #insult #singapore #boss

description:
A Facebook post written by another former employee, which has since made its rounds on social media, claims that her ex-colleague, a young Malaysian worker, had taken her own life in December last year after she faced “constant bullying and insults” by the director of the firm. The post also claimed that her employment was terminated after she failed to achieve sales targets.

The Facebook post was accompanied by a suicide note, which the writer had obtained from the mother of the Malaysian worker.

The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) said that the Malaysian worker did not make a report before her death. Last month, some 11 months later, her mother contacted the ministry on Oct 29.

Why is she raising the incident almost a year after her daughter’s death?
And what did the firm's director have to say, during an interview with @todayonline?

Find out, when you click on the link in bio.

#mom #suicide #investigation #employer #workplacewellness #workplaceculture #workplace #bully #insult #singapore #boss

comments: Everyone is wrong here. If it's true then the director is an asshole. The suicider is selfish enough to not think of the people who loved her. The mother is bad at mothering that her daughter never speaks of anything to her. Probably that kind of "mother" who expects perfection, never really care about her daughter or a dominant bitch of the family. The end.

comments: Doesn't pay to be corrupt
description:
Apart from accepting monetary kickbacks, he also got the women to masturbate him, and give him sex and massages for free. 

A 47-year-old Immigration & Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA) officer was charged today with accepting bribes from two female Chinese nationals between 2018 and last year. The bribes were in exchange for helping the women stay in Singapore by arranging for them to get special passes. 

He appeared in court on Tuesday with the women — Liang Qinglan, 37, and Cheng Wenjuan, 32.

Special passes are issued by either the ICA or Ministry of Manpower. They allow foreigners to stay in Singapore for specific purposes, such as to assist in investigations and attend court proceedings.

The charges Teo faces include: 
- trying to obtain an Apple iPhone X from Liang 
- obtaining a red packet with 188.88 yuan (S$38.50)
- obtaining at least S$2,100 in cash	
- obtaining loans amounting to about 7,000 yuan
- obtaining free sex on several occasions
- obtaining a free massage and masturbation

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#ica #icaofficer #kickbacks #bribe #crime #court

description:
Imagine receiving news that you are dead, when you are in fact alive and kicking. 

For a brief moment this week, startled readers of a French news site had to grapple with the apparent demise of Queen Elizabeth II of England; Pelé, the Brazilian soccer legend; Clint Eastwood; Brigitte Bardot; and dozens of other celebrities and world leaders. 

As it turned out, the website of Radio France Internationale had mistakenly published about 100 prewritten obituaries of prominent figures.

Several hours after the obituaries first ran Monday, the public radio station, which broadcasts in France and abroad, apologised and started taking the reports offline.

It said that unedited drafts had been accidentally published as it moved its website to a new content management system.

Some of those declared dead before their time responded with good humour.
Read their reactions, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Reuters

Photo: Reuters

Part of the Singapore Tourism Board’s SingapoRediscovers campaign.

An eclectic mix of local guided tours and workshops in December will offer a behind-the-scenes look at Geylang's red light district and migrant worker dormitories, SingPost's mail distribution centre and the kelongs off Changi Point, in the inaugural My Community Festival.

Other programmes include tours around Toa Payoh’s funeral parlours, where an undertaker will show participants how bodies are prepared for funerals, and visits to traditional craftsmen including Tay Guan Heng, who is believed to be Singapore’s last joss stick maker.

The festival is being organised by My Community, a non-profit organisation that promotes community heritage by managing community museums and holding neighbourhood tours and festivals.

More details, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @mycommunitysg; SingPost

@singapore @visit_singapore @stb_sg #singaporediscovers

description:
Migrant worker Shermaraja Arunachalam has spent more than half a year cut off from the outside world. He is among more than 300,000 migrant workers in Singapore who have endured lockdown-like conditions since April.

Now, six months later, he and his dormitory mates are only just starting to sense that they may get some reprieve.

While the wider community here is gradually having some normality as they go about their lives, Mr Shermaraja and many migrant workers remain indoors, save for work and essential errands. As part of the measures to ease restrictions for migrant workers to stay safe within and outside the dormitories, from Oct 31, workers who have recovered and those who have tested negative recently under a rostered routine testing regime are allowed to visit recreation centres on their rest days — at staggered time slots. 

Mr Shermaraja gave TODAY a glimpse into his life since returning to work last month after being cooped up for almost half a year. He also talked about his fears battling an invisible enemy — he had no symptoms when he was infected with the coronavirus back in June — as well as his grim encounters with depressed, suicidal workers. More in the link in bio @todayonline.

 (📷: Ili Nadhirah Mansor/TODAY)

description:
Youths hoping to get involved in social causes do not need to rely on a third party to form the bridge for them. It can be as simple as speaking to people in need near their homes, said a social activist at a lunchtime webinar earlier this week. 

Citing the examples of migrant and low-income workers, Mr Cai Yinzhou @yinzjoee told the audience of TODAY’s inaugural Instagram Live webinar series that they can invite these workers for coffee and just chat with them about their lives. He told TODAY later that this type of interaction could help to change perspectives about these workers.

“I think the best kind of interviews, the best insights that you can get, are really from conversations,” said the director of Citizen Adventures, which organises tours to Geylang @geylangadventures and Dakota to raise awareness on social issues specific to the neighbourhoods.

The 30-year-old was responding to a question asked by moderator and CNA presenter Elizabeth Neo about how youths can stay informed about social causes they support, and to whom they ought to be speaking.

Both were part of a panel discussion titled “Activism no longer a dirty word: The rise and impact of youth activism and its future in Singapore”. It was the first in a series of four discussions on issues affecting Singapore society.

They were joined by TODAY senior journalist Navene Elangovan and Ms Dipa Swaminathan @dipagyps, a lawyer and founder of the migrant workers group ItsRainingRaincoats @itsrainingraincoats.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
His fiancee was present in the district court when Gabriel Lim Wei Hng, 28, pleaded guilty to one count each of insulting the modesty of a woman and criminal trespass.

Lim, a business administration executive, was in the men's toilet when he heard voices in the adjacent women's toilet. 

His lawyers argued that in the spur of the moment, he “wanted to take a video of a female using the toilet”. And so, he did. 

He went to the women's toilet, chose the toilet cubicle closest to the entrance and filmed the victim with his mobile phone from above the cubicle door. The woman was in a state of undress and relieving herself.

The victim noticed the phone and shouted, causing Lim to panic. He returned to the men’s toilet to delete the footage before he went back to his office.

Four other charges, relating to similar offences he had previously committed at the same toilet, were taken into consideration during sentencing.

An impulsive act, or a premeditated one? 
Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Unsplash 

#voyeur #voyeurism #toilet #peepingtom #crime #court #singapore

description:
This was possibly her own father’s doing. 

The last thing Khatera saw were the three men on a motorcycle who attacked her just after she left her job at a police station in Afghanistan's central Ghazni province. 

They shot at her and stabbed her in the eyes with a knife. Waking up in hospital, everything was dark.

"I asked the doctors, why I can't see anything? They told me that my eyes are still bandaged because of the wounds. But at that moment, I knew my eyes had been taken from me," she said.

She blames the attack on Taliban militants, and says the assailants acted on a tip-off from her father who vehemently opposed her working outside the home.

The attack on Ms Khatera, 33, is indicative of a growing trend, human rights activists say, of an intense and often violent backlash against women taking jobs, especially in public roles.

Read on, when you click in the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Reuters

#womenempowerment #supportwomen #female #attack #taliban #afghanistan #stabbing #crime #career #independence #humanrights

The last thing Khatera saw were the three men on a motorcycle who attacked her just after she left her job at a police station in Afghanistan's central Ghazni province. 

They shot at her and stabbed her in the eyes with a knife. Waking up in hospital, everything was dark.

"I asked the doctors, why I can't see anything? They told me that my eyes are still bandaged because of the wounds. But at that moment, I knew my eyes had been taken from me," she said.

She blames the attack on Taliban militants, and says the assailants acted on a tip-off from her father who vehemently opposed her working outside the home.

The attack on Ms Khatera, 33, is indicative of a growing trend, human rights activists say, of an intense and often violent backlash against women taking jobs, especially in public roles.

Read on, when you click in the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Reuters

#womenempowerment #supportwomen #female #attack #taliban #afghanistan #stabbing #crime #career #independence #humanrights

This was possibly her own father’s doing. 

The last thing Khatera saw were the three men on a motorcycle who attacked her just after she left her job at a police station in Afghanistan's central Ghazni province. 

They shot at her and stabbed her in the eyes with a knife. Waking up in hospital, everything was dark.

"I asked the doctors, why I can't see anything? They told me that my eyes are still bandaged because of the wounds. But at that moment, I knew my eyes had been taken from me," she said.

She blames the attack on Taliban militants, and says the assailants acted on a tip-off from her father who vehemently opposed her working outside the home.

The attack on Ms Khatera, 33, is indicative of a growing trend, human rights activists say, of an intense and often violent backlash against women taking jobs, especially in public roles.

description:
Goh An Soon, 20, repeatedly stole bags of laundry from a hall at the National University of Singapore, and trespassed into the dormitory whenever he felt the urge to look at women's undergarments.

In the span of less than two months, he took some nine laundry bags with assorted clothing, and trespassed into King Edward VII Hall on eight occasions. 

Among the items he took, were: Two bras from a washing machine, four panties from another washing machine, a laundry bag containing a sports bra and underwear, and a black leather wallet. He also took multiple items of clothing hanging along a common corridor, including two pairs of panties, a bra and several pairs of socks, and a pair of black shorts.

In the span of less than two months, he took some nine laundry bags with assorted clothing, and trespassed into King Edward VII Hall on eight occasions. 

Among the items he took, were: Two bras from a washing machine, four panties from another washing machine, a laundry bag containing a sports bra and underwear, and a black leather wallet. He also took multiple items of clothing hanging along a common corridor, including two pairs of panties, a bra and several pairs of socks, and a pair of black shorts. 

His modus operandi was to check washing machines at the dormitory's launderettes or along corridors for women's undergarments. 

The court heard that he would then take the undergarments to pantry rooms “to look at them up close”, and that he would leave the undergarments behind in these rooms thereafter. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 
 
#nus #student #fetish #court #crime #singapore #undergarmentthief #underwearthief #thief #theft @nus_singapore

description:
A touching true story, of one mother's love. 

Mr Li Hua, 47, has a condition called ankylosing spondylitis, which caused his bones to fuse and his spine to curve forwards.

For more than twenty years, he has relied on his mother to help him get through each day, from preparing meals, to getting dressed and going to the bathroom. It is help that Ms Tang Dongchen, 71, has given with grace.

“I never complained about him and I never told him off,” said Ms Tang. 
“He is my son. It’s not his fault that he’s got this disease.”

To show his gratitude to his mother, Mr Li, who lives in the central Chinese province of Hunan, often plays his favourite Chinese song on the harmonica: In the World, Only Mama is Dear.

Mr Li’s condition began to worsen when he was about 18 and over time he became bent over, his face just a few centimetres from his thighs.

Before Mr Li had a wheelchair, Ms Tang would carry her son on her back, taking him to doctors in search of treatment...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: South China Morning Post 

#foldedman #china #momlife #motherhood #mother #love #unconditionallove

description:
Emma recounted, during an appearance on Jimmy Kimmel Live!: "I was keeping my pregnancy pretty low key but unfortunately my mother has Instagram. Which, mothers and Instagram, it's a bad combination. She definitely spilled the beans."

The 29-year-old actress is currently expecting her first child with her boyfriend Garrett Hedlund. However, she didn’t get to reveal the good news herself, as her mother, Kelly Cunningham, was the one who told her fans through her Instagram account.

"When I said to her, 'Mom, you revealed my pregnancy.' She goes, 'Emma, you announced it!' And I said, 'No I didn't. That was a tabloid.' She goes, 'Oh I didn’t ... that wasn't clear.’ ”

To teach her mum a lesson, Emma blocked her on the photo sharing app.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

The 29-year-old actress is currently expecting her first child with her boyfriend Garrett Hedlund. However, she didn’t get to reveal the good news herself, as her mother, Kelly Cunningham, was the one who told her fans through her Instagram account.

"When I said to her, 'Mom, you revealed my pregnancy.' She goes, 'Emma, you announced it!' And I said, 'No I didn't. That was a tabloid.' She goes, 'Oh I didn’t ... that wasn't clear.’ ”

To teach her mum a lesson, Emma blocked her on the photo sharing app.

description:
Treat yourself :)

Some options include: 

Cafe de Muse, a double-storey Korean cafe at Isetan Scotts that's open 24 hours(!), with a dessert bar on its second floor. @cafedemusesg 

Kafe Utu, which specialises in African food, including a selection of African desserts. These include Nakupenda ($10), a Kenyan-style donut topped with soft serve ice cream, Malindi Halwa (Swahili mochi with coconut yogurt, $10) and Mahamri ($8), Swahili fried bread with coconut flakes and cardamom. @kafeutu 

Apiary, a hipster ice cream specialist that offers some interesting flavours for their house-made ice cream (from $4.20 for a single scoop). There's the eponymous Apiary (wildflower honey ice cream with French nougats), Blue Milk (milk-based ice cream dyed with butterfly pea flowers) and Caramelised Strawberry. @apiary.sg

For the full list of sweet spots, head to the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @wanwan.thaicafe @2amdessertbar @whiskandpaddlesg @8days_eat @8dayssg

comments: Blacklisted them
description:
Twelve Cupcakes is all about sweet bakes, but it seems that working there left a bad taste in the mouths of some employees. 

The homegrown bakery chain has been charged with paying eight of its foreign employees less than their stipulated monthly salaries from 2017 to 2019.

The firm faces 29 counts of contravening rules under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act pertaining to employers of S Pass holders. If convicted, the company could be fined up to S$10,000 or S$20,000 for each charge.

This is not the first time Twelve Cupcakes has been accused of similar offences. 

In 2013, its then-owner and radio DJ Daniel Ong @daniel_ong_singapore  rejected allegations that the firm exploited foreign workers by making them work longer hours than local employees, for low pay and with no overtime remuneration. Mr Ong founded Twelve Cupcakes in 2011 with his ex-wife, Ms Jaime Teo @jmeteo. The couple divorced in 2016.

The chain was sold to Indian tea company Dhunseri Group for S$2.5 million in January 2017.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: @twelvecupcakes

#twelvecupcakes #court #foreignworker #foreignworkers #underpaid

The homegrown bakery chain has been charged with paying eight of its foreign employees less than their stipulated monthly salaries from 2017 to 2019.

The firm faces 29 counts of contravening rules under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act pertaining to employers of S Pass holders. If convicted, the company could be fined up to S$10,000 or S$20,000 for each charge.

This is not the first time Twelve Cupcakes has been accused of similar offences. 

In 2013, its then-owner and radio DJ Daniel Ong @daniel_ong_singapore  rejected allegations that the firm exploited foreign workers by making them work longer hours than local employees, for low pay and with no overtime remuneration. Mr Ong founded Twelve Cupcakes in 2011 with his ex-wife, Ms Jaime Teo @jmeteo. The couple divorced in 2016.

The chain was sold to Indian tea company Dhunseri Group for S$2.5 million in January 2017.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: @twelvecupcakes

#twelvecupcakes #court #foreignworker #foreignworkers #underpaid

comments: The cupcakes are innocent

description:
Three years ago, she discovered a small bump near her right armpit while she was in the shower. For four months, she procrastinated getting it checked.

When she finally did, Ms Vivienne Wong, then 32 (pictured above, right), was diagnosed with breast cancer. 

Because her cancer grew so fast, her doctor urged her to get a mastectomy immediately, which involved removing her entire right breast. “That was one of the most devastating moments,” Ms Wong said. 

Even though she got it reconstructed, it was not the same to her. “It’s dead inside. It’s numb, it’s really just a prosthetic in my chest.”

Ms Wendy New, 42 (pictured above, left), discovered she had breast cancer when she was 39, but opted not to undergo a mastectomy. She recalled how a close male friend had urged her to do it because it was a simple process of cutting off “a piece of meat”.

“People don’t know how to react to cancer patients,” Ms New said. “They don’t need your advice, they just need someone to be there to listen to them. They don’t need you to understand exactly what they are going through, because you wouldn’t.”

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

@bcfsg #breastcancerawareness #breastcancer #womenempowerment

comments: Watch CGO Grey's video of Lockdown productivity: Spaceship you. Basically explains to set boundaries & design work areas in your house so you won't feel overwhelmed or have the line between work & home blurred.  Link:https://youtu.be/snAhsXyO3Ck
description:
After her third visit to the clinic for chest pains, which led her to be referred to a hospital’s accident and emergency department, 20-something year old Adriana (not her real name) decided that she had had enough. She quit her job.

Her first two visits were for headaches from a lack of sleep and stress, and for gastric pains from skipping meals and taking painkillers.

She says her GP (general practitioner) remarked to her: "Nowadays, people either get Covid-19 and suffer, or they don’t and suffer while working."

Then, there’s 25-year-old Stella (not her real name) who also made the difficult decision to resign from her job in the food and beverage industry because her neverending work was starting to affect her mental health.

Stella said she would work 12 to 15 hours a day, from the moment she woke up until past midnight where she went straight to bed. She was also unable to take breaks during the day and was forced to skip many meals.

With “homeworking” taking root amid the Covid-19 pandemic, many employees in Singapore find themselves being pushed to the limits, as the boundaries between work and home become blurred.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

comments: When it is time to promote “let’s stay home n stay safe” the journalists expounded the efficiencies n wonderful WFH arrangements... now it’s time to promote against WFH so as to help retailers in CBD? Perhaps MRT issues are helping to encourage WFH?

Chrissy Teigen and John Legend are grieving, after tragically suffering the miscarriage of their third child.

Chrissy wrote on Instagram: "We are shocked and in the kind of deep pain you only hear about, the kind of pain we've never felt before. We were never able to stop the bleeding and give our baby the fluids he needed, despite bags and bags of blood transfusions. It just wasn't enough."

They had already named him Jack. 

The couple have two children: Luna, four, and Miles, two.

Chrissy added in her post: "Jack worked so hard to be a part of our little family, and he will be, forever. To our Jack — I'm so sorry that the first few moments of your life were met with so many complications, that we couldn't give you the home you needed to survive. We will always love you."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Homeless after being disowned by his parents, Marc Tay Yi Jie turned to scams to pay for his food and accommodation in backpackers’ inns, dormitories and hostels.

Capitalising on the Covid-19 crisis, the 25-year-old unemployed Singaporean began selling items such as NTUC FairPrice supermarket vouchers, surgical masks and hand sanitiser on online marketplaces Carousell and Facebook Marketplace. 

The thing is, he never had these items. 

He also ran loan and camera rental scams. 

In all, he cheated 24 people of S$32,928 before he was arrested.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: iStock file photo

comments: If he wasn’t unemployed, he probably wouldn’t have turn to crimes

Capitalising on the Covid-19 crisis, the 25-year-old unemployed Singaporean began selling items such as NTUC FairPrice supermarket vouchers, surgical masks and hand sanitiser on online marketplaces Carousell and Facebook Marketplace. 

The thing is, he never had these items. 

He also ran loan and camera rental scams. 

In all, he cheated 24 people of S$32,928 before he was arrested.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: iStock file photo

description:
Hell hath no fury like a man scorned. 

On one occasion prior to the murder, the man had pressed a towel over the victim's mouth “in an attempt to kill her”, but released it when she struggled and apologised.

After dating for five years, Bangladeshi worker Ahmed Salim and his girlfriend Nurhidayati Wartono Surata got engaged and planned to get married. 

But during their engagement, Nurhidayati, a domestic worker from Indonesia, started seeing other men. This led Ahmed to ask his mother to find a bride for him back home. 

They continued their relationship despite the circumstances but things came to a head on Dec 30, 2018 at the Golden Dragon Hotel in Geylang when she refused to break up with another foreign worker. 

Ahmed then killed her.

Details of how the murder took place, at the link in bio @todayonline

description:
What are the challenges migrant workers here face when it comes to getting access to justice when they are in legal trouble?

The case of former Indonesian domestic helper Ms Parti Liyani, who was convicted of stealing over S$30,000 worth of items from her employer, and then subsequently acquited has put a spotlight on the issue. 

Checks with lawyers and non-governmental organisations revealed a few systemic issues. Compounding the situation, they have to cope with a loss of income — and the added anxiety — while waiting for their case to conclude, which could take years.

Read the full report in the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Director Spike Lee hails the late actor: "A trooper."

Actor Chadwick Boseman died on Friday (Aug 28) after secretly battling colon cancer for the past four years. 

Lee, 63, admitted he did not know about Chadwick's illness when they were working on the physically demanding shoot for the Netflix movie in Thailand in March last year.

Lee said: "We filmed Da 5 Bloods in Thailand, and it was hot, jungles, mountains, and Chadwick was there with us all the way. I never, ever suspected that anything was wrong. No one knew he was going through treatment, chemotherapy."

"A trooper. He never complained. He was there every single minute, in the moment, and his performance is testament to what he put into that role and all his roles."

Read on, in the link in bio @todayonline

A momentary lapse due to fatigue and an accidental fall left two men in their 20s picking up the pieces of their lives and taking a path completely different from what they had envisioned for themselves.

Mr Aaron Yeo was a hairstylist aspiring to open his own hair salon. 
Mr Melvin Ong was a musician looking to have a career doing what he loves. 

On separate occasions, the two men suffered traumatic injuries that left them paralysed and took away more than just the control of their limbs and movement.

Today, they are still living with their disabilities and are striving to live a full and rewarding life.

Find out how these two men found the grit to keep on going in the #linkinbio

description:
Singapore has confirmed 354 new cases of Covid-19, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a press release on Thursday (July 23).⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
There are eight new community cases based on the ministry's investigations so far. Four are Singaporeans or permanent residents and four are work pass holders.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
In addition, there are five imported cases who had been placed on a stay-home notice upon arrival in Singapore.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 49,098.

There are nine new community cases based on the ministry's investigations so far. One is a Singaporean and eight are work pass holders. In addition, there are three imported cases who had been isolated or placed on a stay-home notice upon arrival in Singapore.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
"The higher number of cases today is mainly due to a batch of test results from the previous day reported to MOH after the 12pm cut-off for yesterday’s reporting," the ministry said.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 48,434.

All you have to do is present your IC to collect your household's pack at any community centre or community club by Aug 2, or residents’ committee centre by July 26.

You may also ask for a Singapore flag at any collection centre to display outside your home.

Visit the #linkinbio for more details

description:
The Ministry of Health has confirmed 347 new cases of Covid-19 on Tuesday (July 14), bringing the total number of infections here to 46,630.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
There are seven new community cases based on the ministry's investigations so far. One is a Singaporean and six are work pass holders.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
In addition, there are two imported cases who had been placed on a stay-home notice upon arrival in Singapore.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The vast majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.

The Ministry of Health has confirmed 183 new cases of Covid-19 on Monday (July 6).⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Three of the community cases are Singaporeans or permanent residents and 20 are Work Pass holders. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The MOH said of the 23 community cases, five were close contacts of earlier cases, and had already been placed on quarantine. Another seven are migrant workers who reside together at a temporary accommodation arranged by their company. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 44,983.⁣⁣⁣

The MOH said of the 23 community cases, five were close contacts of earlier cases, and had already been placed on quarantine. Another seven are migrant workers who reside together at a temporary accommodation arranged by their company. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 44,983.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
More in #linkinbio

description:
Parties continued on the campaign trail on Friday (July 3), speaking to voters across Singapore ahead of the General Election. TODAY's journalists captured some of these moments.

1. Dr Tan Cheng Bock introducing PSP candidate Choo Shaun Ming to Chua Chu Kang residents at a coffeeshop at Teck Whye Lane. 

2. PAP’s secretary-general Lee Hsien Loong met residents in Ang Mo Kio and Yio Chu Kang, where he joined the party’s candidate Yip Hon Weng on the campaign trail. 

3. WP's Sylvia Lim, Pritam Singh and new face Tan Chen Chen meet a resident’s pet parrot during a walkabout near Punggol MRT station. 

4. PAP's new face Edward Chia on a walkbout at Bangkit Road. 

5. SDP's Paul Tambyah greets a resident during his walkabout at Pending Road. 

6. PAP's Dr Vivian Balakrishnan speaking with residents at Bangkit Road. 

7. WP's Sylvia Lim, Pritam Singh and Tan Chen Chen, who is the candidate contesting for Punggol West SMC, on a walkabout near Soo Teck LRT station. 

8. PAP’s Lee Hsien Loong with fellow party candidates greeting residents on the campaign trail.

9. PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock with candidates for Chua Chu Kang GRC Choo Shaun Ming and Francis Yuen taking a selfie with a resident at Blk 9 Teck Whye Lane. 

10. Mr Lee Hsien Loong and Mr Yip Hon Weng sat down together to chat about the new PAP candidate’s campaign so far. 

📸: Ooi Boon Keong, Nuria Ling, Lena Loke, Justin Ong

description:
The MOH discovered nine new Covid-19 infections in two separate households in Block 111 on Tampines Street 11. 

A 66-year-old Singaporean man who works at Leo Dormitory was confirmed to have the disease on June 23. Six of his household members later tested positive. 

Then, on June 27, a 15-year-old Singaporean girl from a separate household reported sick and tested positive for the coronavirus. One of her household members also contracted the disease.

However, no links have been established between the two households so far, the MOH said. 

More details in the #linkinbio

From the east to the west, parties fanned out across Singapore on Wednesday (July 1) to canvass support after Nomination Day. TODAY's journalists captured some of these moments. 

1. Workers’ Party team for East Coast GRC taking a break during a walkabout at a hawker centre in Bedok North.

2. Mr Tan Chuan-Jin from the People's Action Party's Marine Parade GRC team taking a wefie at Haig Rd market.

3. Peoples Voice's Gilbert Goh doing outreach at the food court at Punggol Plaza.

4. PAP's Dr Ng Eng Hen talking to a Bishan resident near Junction 8.

5. WP's team members for East Coast GRC at a walkabout in Bedok North.

6. PAP's Marine Parade GRC team posing for photo after walkabouts at Haig Road market.

7. Singapore Democratic Party member Paul Tambyah, who is contesting in Bukit Panjang SMC, during a walkabout at Block 259, Bangkit Road. 

8. Mr Jose Raymond meeting a resident while distributing his Potong Pasir manifesto at Blk 117 Potong Pasir Avenue 1.

9. PAP's Sembawang GRC team seen making their rounds at a coffee shop at Block 406 Sembawang Drive.

10. PAP's Pasir Ris - Punggol GRC team at Punggol Central on Wednesday morning speaking to residents and handing out flyers. 

Read about Day 2 of campaigning so far in the #linkinbio

description:
The Ministry of Health confirmed 142 new Covid-19 cases on Friday (June 19). This is the lowest daily tally in more than two months, equalling the 142 cases reported on April 8.

There is one new community case involving a prison inmate on a social visit pass, who arrived in Singapore before border control measures were implemented. "He had been segregated from the general inmate population since his admission to Changi Prison Complex on June 6, and was tested positive for Covid-19," MOH said.

The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.

The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 41,615.

description:
The Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed 151 new cases of Covid-19 on Tuesday (June 16).⁣
⁣
This is the first time the daily tally has fallen below 200 in more than 2 months, since 191 cases were reported on April 11.⁣
⁣
There are two new community cases based on the ministry's investigations so far. Both are work pass holders, with no new Singaporean or permanent resident cases.⁣
⁣
The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.⁣
⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 40,969.

description:
Unable to tolerate her employers’ repeated assaults any longer, a foreign domestic helper climbed out of the living room window of a fourth-storey Sengkang flat and sat on a ledge. 
Ms Amandeep Kaur, then aged 27, was eventually rescued by a foreign worker who was involved in the painting of the surrounding blocks of flats.

Her employers —  Mohammad Tasleem, 41, and Farha Tehseen, 39 — who claimed trial to multiple counts of abuse against Ms Kaur were found guilty of all charges on Tuesday (June 9). #linkinbio for the full story

description:
The Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed 218 new cases of Covid-19 on Tuesday (June 9).⁣
⁣
This is the lowest daily tally reported here which MOH has not attributed to fewer swabs being conducted, as was the case on some days.⁣

description:
Singapore has confirmed 261 new cases of Covid-19, said the Ministry of Health on Friday (June 5).⁣
⁣
Out of the 11 community cases, six are Singaporeans or permanent residents, while five are work pass holders. Among the 11 cases, six are linked to previously confirmed cases and have been quarantined.
⁣
The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.⁣
⁣
According to the ministry, the lower number of cases reported today is partly due to fewer swabs being conducted.⁣
⁣
The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 37,183.

description:
Singapore has confirmed 517 new Covid-19 cases, said the Ministry of Health on Thursday (June 4). These include 15 community cases, the highest since May 20. Two involve Singaporeans or permanent residents, while 13 are work pass holders.

According to the ministry, all 15 cases are close contacts of earlier confirmed cases and have been quarantined.

The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.

More in the #linkinbio

description:
The Ministry of Health on Wednesday (June 3) said that there are seven community cases. One case is a Singaporean or permanent resident, while six are work pass holders.

The majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories.

This brings the total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore to 36,405.

description:
🎨When 19-year-old Russell Chong heard about the surge in Covid-19 cases among migrant workers here, he wanted to do something for them in his own way.

Along with several other School of the Arts graduates, he raised S$15,000 for a migrant worker non-profit group by selling postcards online and distributed another 10,000 postcards to the workers for them to write home. 
#linkinbio to find out how he did it.

description:
Working out, baking and decluttering wardrobes are a few of the activities Singaporeans have turned to during the circuit breaker to keep busy and stay sane at home.

But some have gone a step further, by using these activities to raise money to give to those in need.

Among them are Ms Germaine Tan and Mr Zh Abdul Hafeez who have started fund-raising projects for foreign workers in the form of selling pre-loved clothes and starting a fitness challenge.

#linkinbio to learn more about how people are turning circuit breaker hobbies into charitable projects.

comments: Thanks for being here and sacrificing! Eid mubarak to you!
description:
Alone in her bedroom in a HDB rental flat, Ms Siti Fatimah Awang, a Malaysian who works as a cleaner at a gym in Chai Chee, was waiting for a video call on Sunday (May 24) morning.⁣
⁣
It was a Hari Raya Puasa morning unlike any other for her family.⁣ Her husband, a construction worker who also works here, is not allowed to leave a temporary isolation facility for foreign workers.⁣ Their sons, aged seven and two, are being cared for separately by her sister in Malaysia and a babysitter back home in Malaysia.⁣
⁣
When the family finally had the call that lasted half an hour, Ms Siti Fatimah broke down in her Bukit Merah rental flat.⁣ “I told my husband I’d be strong but when I saw my kids, I couldn’t hide my feelings any longer,” she said. ⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to read more about the many Malaysians who spent Hari Raya in Singapore.

The Ministry of Health's (MOH) update on Monday (May 18) brings the total number of cases here to 28,343.⁣
⁣
“The lower number of cases today is partly due to fewer tests being processed as one testing laboratory is reviewing its processes following an earlier apparatus calibration issue, and will need time to ramp up its testing capacity,” MOH said.⁣
⁣
The vast majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories, while 2 cases are Singaporeans or Permanent Residents. ⁣

description:
These facilities comprise: ⁣
⁣
▶️ Community care facilities⁣
▶️ Community recovery facilities⁣
▶️ Swab isolation facilities ⁣
▶️ Dorm isolation facilities.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Volunteers can come forward through the SG Healthcare Corps portal.
⁣⁣
These volunteers need not be medically trained and the Ministry of Health will deploy these volunteers based on the skills they have to offer.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
For instance, some volunteers could be sent to help swab testing teams with testing patients.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#linkinbio to learn more.

description:
On April 23, the total number of people infected with Covid-19 crossed the 10,000-mark, 91 days after the first case was reported in Singapore on Jan 23. ⁣
⁣
As the nation battles a worsening Covid-19 crisis, the authorities face criticism by some for their response, particularly for their inability to prevent the ongoing viral spread within foreign worker dormitories. Others question why the drastic moves taken today, such as the newly extended national circuit breaker and mandatory face mask policy, were not done sooner.⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to read more in this weekend's edition of #thebigread⁣ as @todayonline examines how the Singapore authorities have been tackling the Covid-19 outbreak since it first landed in the country three months ago. ⁣

description:
On April 23, the total number of people infected with Covid-19 crossed the 10,000-mark, 91 days after the first case was reported in Singapore on Jan 23. ⁣
⁣
As the nation battles a worsening Covid-19 crisis, the authorities face criticism by some for their response, particularly for their inability to prevent the ongoing viral spread within foreign worker dormitories. Others question why the drastic moves taken today, such as the newly extended national circuit breaker and mandatory face mask policy, were not done sooner.⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to read more in this weekend's edition of #thebigread⁣ as @todayonline examines how the Singapore authorities have been tackling the Covid-19 outbreak since it first landed in the country three months ago. ⁣

description:
The Ministry of Health on Saturday (April 25) announced 618 new cases of Covid-19, bringing the total number of infections here to 12,693.⁣
⁣
This is the second day in a row where the daily tally is under 1,000, after four straight days where the number of new cases was above the mark.⁣
⁣
The majority of the new patients are work permit holders residing in dormitories housing migrant workers.⁣
⁣
Of the new cases, 7 cases are Singaporeans or Permanent Residents.⁣

comments: These covid numbers like COE prices and ERP so high they are shocking at first but after while you get desensitized and don’t even notice it any more..

description:
897 new cases of Covid-19 have been confirmed, said the Ministry of Health in a preliminary update on Friday (April 24).⁣
⁣
This brings the total number of cases here to 12,075 and is the first time in five days that the number of new daily infections dropped below 1,000.⁣
⁣
The vast majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories. ⁣
⁣
13 of the new cases are Singaporeans and Permanent Residents.⁣

description:
Mr Richard Rosales from the Philippines has been quarantined in the Jurong Penjuru Dormitory since work was suspended on April 13. ⁣
He has been using @tiktok.singapore to remain upbeat and document his days in the dorm for his wife and three children back home by posting daily videos. ⁣
“They are worried about me here, about my condition but they feel a little bit relieved when they see my videos and I make them laugh so that’s good,” he said.⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to read and watch how quarantined foreign workers are taking to TikTok to entertain themselves and assure their family back home they are okay. #covid19 #singapore #singaporenews #stayhomesg #stayhome #circuitbreaker

comments: Stay happy guys.. no matter what happens. Positive energy all u need.

1,037 new cases of Covid-19 were reported by the Ministry of Health on Thursday (April 23), bringing the total number of infections here to 11,178.⁣
⁣
This is the fourth day in a row that the number of daily infections was more than 1,000.⁣
⁣
The vast majority of the new patients are work permit holders residing in dormitories housing migrant workers.⁣
⁣
Of the new cases, 21 cases are Singaporeans or Permanent Residents.

Foreign worker dormitories have been in the spotlight in recent weeks due to the spike in Covid-19 cases in the facilities.
TODAY’s visual correspondent Nuria Ling visited three dormitories – Westlite Papan, Tampines Dormitory and S11 Dormitory – to find out more about the living conditions and what officers from the inter-agency teams have been doing to help manage the facilities.
The visit was arranged by the Manpower Ministry and was filmed on Tuesday (April 21) before the new circuit breaker restrictions were announced.
Read more: https://tdy.sg/3eHiVLz

⁣
This brings the total number of cases here to 10,141, and is the third consecutive day that Singapore has reported more than 1,000 new cases in a day.⁣
⁣
The vast majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories with fifteen of the new cases comprising Singaporeans and Permanent Residents.⁣

A manager of a dormitory that came under fire on Tuesday (April 21) for locking 20 foreign workers in their room after one of them tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday said the facility had “no choice” but to do so for the safety of some 800 workers living there.

Both the dormitory manager, who wanted to be known only as Mr Thng, and Ms Reena Wong, the design director of the men’s employer V Spec Engineering & Supplies, told @todayonline that the men are no longer locked up, unlike before. 
Ms Wong defended the dormitory's actions on Monday: “Don’t tell me your colleague got virus, you still go and walk around? Cannot be what! For the sake of every man at the dorm, we as an employer told them not to go around. For goodness’ sake, it is only temporary.” #linkinbio for the full story.

Ms Wong defended the dormitory's actions on Monday: “Don’t tell me your colleague got virus, you still go and walk around? Cannot be what! For the sake of every man at the dorm, we as an employer told them not to go around. For goodness’ sake, it is only temporary.” #linkinbio for the full story.

description:
There are 1,111 new cases of Covid-19 in Singapore, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Tuesday (April 21).⁣
⁣
This brings the total number of infections here to 9,125, and is the second day in a row where the number of daily new cases crossed 1,000.⁣
⁣
The vast majority of the new cases are work permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories, said MOH. Twenty cases are Singaporeans and Permanent Residents.⁣ #linkinbio to learn more

description:
The Ministry of Health (MOH) announced 1,426 new cases on April 20 bringing the total number of #covid19 infections in Singapore to 8,014.⁣
⁣
1,369 cases are those who are residing in the dormitories.⁣
⁣
There were 25 cases in the community with 18 Singaporeans or Permanent Residents, and 7 work pass holders.⁣
⁣
MOH said that the number of new cases in the community has decreased, from an average of 39 cases per day in the week before, to an average of 29 per day in the past week.⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to learn more.⁣
⁣
⁣

description:
Several Malaysians who have chosen to remain in Singapore to work during their government-imposed Movement Control Order have found themselves caught in a bind. ⁣
⁣
Most have been asked to take unpaid leave during the circuit breaker period here and are unable to take on part-time jobs by law.⁣
⁣
These work permit holders are hesitant to return to Malaysia at the moment for fear that they will be unable to return to Singapore.⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to learn more of the quandary faced by such Malaysian workers here.

The Ministry of Health (MOH) on Friday (April 10) announced that there were 𝟏𝟗𝟖 new cases of Covid-19, as the total number of cases in Singapore surged past the 2,000-mark.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Three new clusters have emerged:⁣⁣
⁣⁣
▶️ A dormitory in Sungei Kadut Avenue⁣⁣
▶️ A renovation site at the National University Hospital⁣
▶️ The Immigrations and Checkpoint Authority (ICA) Building in Kallang.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The latest cases bring the total number of confirmed Covid-19 infections here to 𝟐,𝟏𝟎𝟖. ⁣
Infographic: Anam Musta'ein/TODAY ⁣
#linkinbio to read the full report. #covid19 #singaporenews

description:
Former Cabinet Minister Yaacob Ibrahim on Tuesday (April 7) apologised for his remark in a Facebook post that has drawn ire from online users for being “insensitive”. The post, which was put up on Sunday by the MP for Jalan Besar GRC, was about the inconveniences that residents in his area had experienced due to foreign domestic workers and foreign workers congregating on Sundays at an open space next to Kallang MRT Station.

Dr Yaacob, who put up the post along with a picture of the empty area, wrote: “But it takes a virus to empty the space.” He has since taken down the post after initially removing the line and adding a clarification note. #linkinbio to read more.

comments: Dear SIR, it is very good you did apologise. Thank you so much on behalf of the migrant workers here in Singapore!

description:
The Ministry of Health announced 66 new cases of Covid-19 in Singapore on Monday (April 6), bringing the total number of infections here to 1,375. One is an imported case,while 65 are local  transmitted. 
Among the domestic cases, MOH has established links to existing clusters for 35 cases — with 24 linked to clusters at foreign worker dormitories and 11 linked to non-dormitory clusters. #linkinbio to learn more. Infographic: Anam Musta’ein/TODAY

comments: The policy necessarily applies broad strokes. But I'm glad an appeal system is in place.
description:
Ms Vivien Goh, who performs as a clown and does ventriloquism at events, was hoping to qualify for the Government’s recently-announced support measures for the self-employed. She has seen a spate of cancellations for her shows since the start of this year, and has done only one show this month, down from her usual 12.

However, she does not qualify for Sirs as she rents a flat on River Valley Road with an annual value of S$20,000, well over the qualifying criterion for the scheme. 
Like several other freelancers, she intends to submit an appeal to MOM and suggested that the authorities also defer the Central Provident Fund's MediSave instalment payments for freelancers as another way to help them. #linkinbio to read more. #covid19 #singaporenews

comments: How do you know u are qualify? And how do I appeal?

comments: Good job SG government👍👍
description:
Less than 24 hours after Mr Armel Sharil was sleeping rough at Kranji MRT Station, he now has a roof over his head for the next two weeks.

His employer found him a hostel at Clarke Quay and  told him that he did not have to pay a single cent. “It’s a bit far from my workplace in Jurong East but it’s okay. I’m not choosy,” he said.

On Thursday (March 19), @todayonline had reported on the plight of Mr Armel and several other Malaysian workers who had to spend the night near Kranji MRT Station as they had yet to find temporary housing after entering Singapore to avoid the nationwide lockdown in Malaysia, which took effect on Wednesday.  Following the report, the Ministry of Manpower spokesperson said in a statement that 14 workers were picked up from the location later in the night, and brought to a temporary relief centre managed by the Ministry of Social and Family Development at Jurong East, while longer-term housing arrangements were made.  There has also been an outpouring of support from Singaporeans for Malaysian workers without a place to stay, with many offering to house the workers in their own homes or provide them with food and blankets. #linkinbio for the full story. #covid_19 #singaporenews

There has also been an outpouring of support from Singaporeans for Malaysian workers without a place to stay, with many offering to house the workers in their own homes or provide them with food and blankets. #linkinbio for the full story. #covid_19 #singaporenews

Less than 24 hours after Mr Armel Sharil was sleeping rough at Kranji MRT Station, he now has a roof over his head for the next two weeks.

His employer found him a hostel at Clarke Quay and  told him that he did not have to pay a single cent. “It’s a bit far from my workplace in Jurong East but it’s okay. I’m not choosy,” he said.

comments: As you can see, there are many sides of the issue. As we look at the legal pov, there are more rights for women to exercise that extends beyond taking care of the family. Women are often seen as the caretaker of the family, hence more time is dedicated to home, which companies see as less time for work. Hence, companies are less willing to pay higher wages to women. On the other hand, the notion that men are seen as more powerful and hence receive more pay is changing and that idea will be dissolved in the distant future. Nonetheless, with changing family values, societies are still struggling with the idea that women are now working. Hence, we have yet to understand and decide how women will play a role both at work and home and what approaches companies should take to resolve this issue especially considering whether it is in their financial interest to do so.
